5 INTRODUCTION As a result of deflation following the post-war speculation the year 1921 records many changes in prices and values and abnormally low prices offered for farm products. Financial conditions did not warrant the selling of a large amount of farm products as the price offered was not sufficient to pay tor cost of production. The general slide in prices seemed to hit the farmer first and hardest In order to settle outstanding debts he was forced to liquidate to some extent The records as taken !»■ assessors show that corn remaining on the farm April 1, 1921, equaled per cent of last year's crop, oats equaled 12 per cent, and wheat 13 This grain was exclusivp of any reserved for feed. Livestock hows a drop in number due to easy liquidation and comparative prices nore near to normal, as a result of which much livestock was sold. CLIMATIC AND SOIL CONDITIONS On account of its size and location. Nebraska records many differ noes In a crop year from east to west and from north to south. The wing <eason varies considerable from north to south and from east to il conditions vary from county to county, and even within unties being a heavy black loam in some and loose sandy soil in others Lands adjoining rivers affect materially the production of the different counties Of which they form a part, while lands under irrigation show much heavier production of those crops commonly raised on irrigated Aside from these conditions, which must always be taken into ation. the temperature and precipitation affect largely the produc - i crop. General lessened precipitation with higher temperatures ral lessened precipitation with higher temperatures during the summer months of June and August materially affected the yields. Local drouth areas reflect the lack of moisture in the size of the crops produced Some western counties as Deuel. Hitchcock, parts of Lincoln and Red Willow show a lower production from these causes. The a. comprising Franklin. Kearney, Phelps, Harlan, southern Buffalo Hall. Adams, and Webster show a decided effect upon the production due to drouth conditions. Wind and hail in Cass did much local damage to corn CULTIVATED CROPS According to the April 1 report area of cultivated crops for 1921 wa thousand and fifty as compared with eight thousand, four hundred four a submitted by the assessors, the total sixteen million, four hundred seven sixteen million, one hundred seventy - res in 1920. CORN Of the cultivated crops reporttil coin occupies the place of proini lit'lice wilh an acerage of seven million, four hundred eighteen thousand, seven hundred as compared with seven million, five hundred Sixty thOU :and. three hundred fifty-five reported for 192<>

6 ■TATS OK NKBBAKKA The corn production tor 1921 totals two hundred eight million, seven hundred thirty-two thousand, two hundred twelve bushels as compared with two hundred fifty-five million, five hundred forty-four thousand, eight hundred sixteen for 1920. This is accounted for both in decreased acre - age and decreased yield per acre caused by drouth in some sections in August. With a value of 50 cents per bushel in 1920 and 22 cents per bushel in 1921, it is easily seen why Nebraska's corn crop yielded so little to the producer. WHEAT Winter wheat reports an acreage of three million, seven hundred sixty-one thousand, six hundred eighty-three for 1921, an increase of four hundred twenty-seven thousand, one hundred thirty-eight over 1920, and more than forty-five thousand acres over the highest acreage for the last six years. The average yield is 14.4 bushels, being 2.22 bushels below the ten-year average. The total production of winter wheat was fifty-four million with a value of forty-six million as compared with a production of fifty-eight million and a value of ninety-three million for 1920. The value per bushel was approximately half that of 1920. The change from spring wheat to winter wheat and oats is noticeable throughout the state. Oats, barley, and rye also showed the reaction from post-w and with larger acreages of oats and rye showed decreased Barley showed greatly decreased acreages in many POTATOES The acreage of potatoes was increased from eighty hundred thirty-nine in 1920 to one hundred two thousand and seventy-foi in 1921, this being an increase of approximately 40 per cent. The avera* yield for 1921 being eighty bushels as compared with ninety-eight bushei for 192p, the total production was consequently lowered below that i 1920. This reacted somewhat on the price and tended to raise it. Th grading law resulted in raising the quality of the commercial crop an thus combined with the lower yield to stiffen the price, with the resu that the state average was 10 cents per bushel higher than last year, eve though the prices of other products were lowering FRUITS AND OTHER MINOR CROPS Due to late frosts fruits became a negligible quantity, and even in the face of falling prices the price of fruits to the consumer remained firm LIVESTOCK— CATTLE As previously mentioned, livestock, especially cattle, was a product which was easily liquidated. As a result the decrease in cattle for the state averaged 7 per cent, with mi average of 22 per cent decrease in

mi I M ountic showed a decrease as high as he counties more largely devoted to livestock ■ii POULTRY products proved a valuable asset to the farmer, ven hundred thirty-three thousand, eight hundred ,V lr dozen birds on farms and close to twelve million in Nebraska irrts over three months old. N'ebraskans found that poultry and products showed a source of income which had heretofore been inexplored. The assessors' returns for 1921 show seven hundred jusand. six hundred fifty-eight dozen of birds with a value of illy seven million dollars. When it is considered that both number submitted to the assessor, were necessarily conservative, the Nebraska flocks have not suffered heavily due to the liquidation. Poultry being easily replaced becofes a most liquid Of the fifty million dollars annual income from poultry and its ximately twenty million dollars is from live poultry.
